$\begin{array}{cccc}
F: & \mathbb{R}^3 & \rightarrow  & \mathbb{R}^2 \\

\end{array}$
$\begin{array}{cccc}
G: & \mathbb{R}^2 & \rightarrow  & \mathbb{R}^2 \\
  & (x, y) & \longrightarrow & (x+y, x-2y)
\end{array}$

answer1: $(G\circ F)(x, y, z)=(x+y-z, -2x+y+2z)$ and $(F\circ G)$ does not exist
answer2: $(F\circ G)(x, y, z)=(x+y-z, -2x+y+2z)$and $(G\circ F)$ does not exist
answer3: $(G\circ F)(x, y, z)=(F\circ G)(x, y, z)=(x+y-z, -2x+y+2z)$
answer4: $(G\circ F)(y, x-z)=(x+y-z, -2x+y+2z)$ and $(F\circ G)(x, y)=(x+y, x-2y)$

question:
Find the solutions of the following linear system, given the values of the parameters $\alpha,\beta,\gamma\in\mathbb{R}$:
$$\begin{cases}
-x &- &4y &- &4z &= &\alpha \\ 
x &- &3y &- &z &= &\beta \\ 
2x &+ &4y &+ &z &= &\gamma
\end{cases}$$
answer1: For every choice of $\alpha,\beta,\gamma\in\mathbb{R}$, the linear system has a unique solution, which is $\left(\frac{-\alpha+12\beta+8\gamma}{29},\,\frac{3\alpha-7\beta+5\gamma}{29},\,\frac{-10\alpha+4\beta-7\gamma}{29}\right)$.
answer2: The system has no solution for $\alpha=\beta=\gamma=0$, and for all other choices of $\alpha,\beta,\gamma\mathbb{R}$ the system has a unique solution which is $\left(\alpha+3\beta-\gamma,\,\gamma,\,\beta-\gamma\right)$.
answer3: The sistem has no solutions for every choice of $\alpha,\beta,\gamma \in \mathbb{R}$.
answer4: For every choice of $\alpha,\beta,\gamma \in \mathbb{R}$, the system has infinite solutions, which are $\left(\alpha-\beta+\gamma+z,\,1+z,\,z\right)$ for every $z\in\mathbb{R}$.

Consider the subsets  $\displaystyle A=\{(1, 1, 1), (0, 1, 1), (1, 2, 3)\}$ and $\displaystyle B=\left\{(1, 1, 1), \left(-\frac{2}{3}, \frac{1}{3}, \frac{1}{3}\right), \left(0, -\frac{1}{2}, \frac{1}{2}\right)\right\}$ of $\mathbb{R}^3$. Choose the right answer:
answer1: $B$ is an orthogonal basis of $\mathbb{R}^3$ but $A$ isn't an orthogonal basis of $\mathbb{R}^3$
answer2: $A$ is an orthogonal basis of $\mathbb{R}^3$ but $B$ isn't an orhtogonal basis of $\mathbb{R}^3$

Find the solutions of the following linear system:
$$\begin{cases}
2x & + & y & + & z & - & t & = & 0 \\
x & - & 2y & - & z & + & 2t & = & 1 \\
x & + & y & + & z & - & t & = & 0
\end{cases}$$
answer1: The solutions of the system are of the form $\left(0,\,y,\,0,\,1+y\right)$ for every $y\in\mathbb{R}$.
answer3: The system has $\left(0,\,0,\,0,\,1\right)$ as its unique solution.
answer4: The system has $\left(0,\,y,\,0,\,z\right)$ as solutions for every $y,z\in\mathbb{R}$.

question: It is possible to compute $A \cdot B $ if

answer2: $A$ and $B$ are both $n\times m$, $n\neq m$ matrices
answer3: the number of the rows of $A$ is equal to the columns of $B$
answer4: the number of the columns of $A$ is equal to the columns of $B$

Find the solutions $\left(\text{in } \mathbb{C}^2\right)$ of the following linear system:
$$\begin{cases}
z &- &iw &= &1 \\
iz &- &w &= &1
\end{cases}$$
answer1: The system has $\bigg(\frac{1-i}{2},\frac{-1+i}{2}\bigg)$ as unique solution.
answer3: The system has $(z,-iz)$ as solution for every $z\in\mathbb{C}$.
answer4: The system has $\bigg(\frac{1-i}{2},\frac{1+i}{2}\bigg)$ as unique solution.

answer1: If the kernel of a linear transformation $T:\mathbb{R}^3\longrightarrow \mathbb{R}^3$ is $\left\{(0,0,0)\right\}$, then $T$ is an isomorphism.
answer2: If the kernel of a linear transformation $T:\mathbb{R}^3\longrightarrow \mathbb{R}^4$ is $\left\{(0,0,0)\right\}$, then $T$ is an isomorphism.
answer3: If the kernel of a linear transformation $T:\mathbb{R}^2\longrightarrow \mathbb{R}^3$ is $\left\{(0,0)\right\}$, then $T$ is an isomorphism.
answer4: If the kernel of a linear transformation $T:\mathbb{R}^3\longrightarrow \mathbb{R}^3$ is $\left\{(0,0,x):x\in\mathbb{R}\right\}$, then $T$ is an isomorphism.

Let $z\in\mathbb{C}$ be a complex number. Then we always have:

Find the solution of the following system:
$$\begin{cases}
&x &+ &y &+ &z &= &0 \\ 
&-x &- &y &+ &2z &= &-1 \\ 
&x &+ &y &- &5z &= &2
\end{cases}$$
answer1:
The system has infinitely many solutions depending on one parameter:
$$\left( -y+\dfrac{1}{3},y, -\frac{1}{3}\right),\, \forall y\in\mathbb{R}$$.
answer2:
The system has infinitely many solutions depending on two parameters:
$$\left( -y+\dfrac{1}{3}z,y, z\right),\, \forall y,z\in\mathbb{R}$$.

Solve the following linear system:
$$\begin{cases}
x & + & 3y & - & z & + & w & = & -2 \\
3x & - & y & - & 3z & - & 4w & = & 1 \\
2x & + & 3y & - & 5z & + & w & = & -3
\end{cases}$$
answer1: The solutions of the system are of the form $\bigg(\frac{22w+7}{15},\,\frac{-7w-7}{10},\,\frac{11w+11}{30}\bigg)$ for every $w\in\mathbb{R}$.
answer3: The system has $\left(1,\,2,\,6,\,-2\right)$ as its unique solution.
answer4: The system has $\left(3w,\,w-1,\,2w,\,w\right)$ as solution for every $w\in\mathbb{R}$.

question: The significance level for a hypothesis test is $0.05$. Choose the correct interpretation.
answer1: The probability to make a Type $I$ error is $0.05$.
answer2: The probability of making a Type $II$ error is $0.95$.
answer3: The probability that the sample is randomly selected is $0.05$.
answer4: The probability, that the null hypothesis will be rejected is $0.05$.

The distance (in miles) from each plant ($i$) to the respective distributing centers ($j$) is given below:

\[
\begin{array}{c|c|c|c|c}
\text{Plant Dist. Center} & \text{1} & \text{2} & \text{3}  & \text{4}  \\
\text{1} & 800  & 1300 &  400 & 700\\
\text{2} & 1100 & 1400 &  600 & 1000 \\
\text{3} & 600  & 1200 &  800 & 900\\
\end{array}
\]	

The freight cost for each shipment is $100.50?$ per mile. Use the transportation simplex method to determine how much should be shipped from each plant to each of the distribution centers each month, to minimize the total shipping cost. Use the minimum cost rule to obtain an initial basic feasible solution.

answer1: The $ABC$ plane has equation $x-y+1=0$ and $D=(4, 5, 6)$ belongs to $ABC$.
answer2: The $ABC$ plane has equation $x+y+1=0$ and $D=(4, -5, 7)$ belongs to $ABC$.
answer3: The $ABC$ plane has equation $2x-y+3=0$ and $D=(2, 7, 6)$ belongs to $ABC$.
answer4: The $ABC$ plane has equation $2x+y+3=0$ and $D=(-1, -1, 0)$ belongs to $ABC$.
